availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Omnium febrium causa latet in sanguine

notesStmt.note: Also includes: Charltoniana hypothesis de sanguinis ad partium nutritionem ineptitudine est rationi dissentanea.

Reproduction of original in the Harvard University Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Omnium Febrium cauſa latet in ſanguine.
div.l: QUid tandem Archiatri ſpondent oracla Phoebis
Ars ſua languet iners, unâ cum peſte tot annos
Bella gesrens, nequeat Febrilem excindere gentem.
Dum Natura ſuas humori aperire lacunas
Perget, quasrutili latices, quas lacteus imber
Complent; pèrque illos dum nutrimenta canales
Diſtribuens, reparante Chylo diſpendia ſanguis
Lambens nativos remeanti flumine Venas,
Circuit humanum repetitis curſibus orbem.
Dum Caeca ambitio, & dominandi inſana cupido
Sanguinis exagitat partes; civilibus armis
Cruda rebellabunt maſſae dum ſemina; ſanguis
Dum fermenteſcit, propriíſque ebullit in antris
Efferus, humano Febris non exulat orbe:
Sanguisalit, torrétqueidem praecordia ſanguis.
Hinc prodit magnâ Furiarum ſepta catervâ
Febris, & immenſo diffundit germina partu,
Ambiguum variis praevertens Protea formis.
Sanguis enim, à propriâ deſciſcens indole, ſumptâ
Auſterâ, nimio pepſin pervertit acore
Nutritii ſucci: ſimulac turgeſcere caepit,
Cruda fluit reliquo nondum aſſimilata liquori
Pars laticis, motúmque ciet; caecúmque tumultum
Spiritus intùs agit, molíſque ſuíque ruinam
Nixus, victricem nativa in viſcera flammam
Convertit; molitur enim (mirabile dictu)
Nativum occultâ tectum torrere favillâ,
Haud interruptos nunquam reparando calores
Continuo accenſas nutrire bitumine flammas.
Sed ſuperans Nitrum teneris ſua ſpicula nervis
Inſigit, torpétque gelu conſtricta medulla:
Hinc rigor, hinc gelidus coit in praecordia ſanguis,
Genva quatit, ſpaſmos ciet, irritátque tremores.
Unica ſic multas morboſa Tragoedia ſcenas
Exhibet; & variâ ludit larvata figurâ
Uſque inteſtinos agitans in ſanguine motus
Febris, Phoenomeníſque ſuis, Phaſibúſque malignis
Stultitiam Medico viſa eſt portendere mundo:
Nam dum, Febrilis quo ſub Duce militat ignis,
Diſceptant, docto promunt deliria mundo.
ERGO
Non Succi, Charltone, tui, non utraque Bilis,
Non Pituita tenax illi vernacula morbo
Materia: immenſum rubri maris aequor arandum,
Ut verae pateant cauſae, quae mille peruſtis
Ignibus inſtaurant vires, quae pabula, vel quae
Arida venturae praemittunt pignora flammae.

div.head: Charltoniana Hypotheſis de Sanguinis ad partium nutritionem Ineptitudine eſt rationi diſſentanea.
div.l:
SAtque ſupér
que datum eſt Erroribus, uſ
que vagari
Heu! miſeré abduci ſpernit foelicior AEtas.
Novimus abſtruſos, Te non famulante, receſſus
Naturae, vegetas quáque elicit undique Vires.
Novimus & varios ductus, varióſque meandros,
Quêis Sanguis generoſa ſuis alimenta miniſtrat
Partibus, & totum reficit vitalibus undis.
Undique luxuriat Sanguis, ſcatet undique ſuccus
Nectaris, & corpus divinâ aſpergine tingit:
Nobilis inde bibit Vena, nervus & inde rigatur,
Indéque Clavigeri quod fecerit Herculis artús.
Nullum munus obit corpus, nî vivida Virtus
Sanguinis inſervit, ſi non eſt maximus Author;
Fruſtrà ſudatum: fruſtrà ſulcavimus omnes
Purpureum hoc pelagus; Melior dum Drakeus Ille
Harvaeus paritèr noſtrum circa Microco / mum
Navigat, atque ſinus ſcrutatur, & aequoris orbes.
Ille tulit partes quî omnes inviſit eundo
Sanguis, quî partes gratae tranſmittere fonti
Gaudent; & mutuo penſatur munere munus.
Spiritus hinc ſaliunt, turma officioſa, miniſtri,
Divino & flatu ſpirant vitámque vigorémque;
Nec quicquid ſapiet (Chartono obſtante) cerebrum
Nî (quaſi Caſtaliâ) priùs hâc tingatur in undâ.
Inde Roſas petis, alma Venus, petis inde, Corinna
Oris Virgineum decus, &, quo carpimur, ignem.
Ipſa vel Invidia, heu! macreſcens rebus opimis
Pulchrior ore nitet, diſtentáque ſanguine gaudet
Si minus officium praeſtat, ſi ſubtrahat almos
Virtutum influxus, facies, quaſi territa, pallet,
Lethifer & toto graffatur corpore Morbus.
div.closer:
Jul. 5. 1681. In die Comit.
Reſp. pro gradu M. B. Guliel. Hill, Coll. D. Joan.
